0766C536D41944848A127D94187329E7.description: Identify explanations of natural phenomena that have been refined as new evidence has been revealed.

779AD93C756C4A10882AB5951439D77C.description: Discuss processes that can be used to validate evidence and explanations.

2FB76C6CCF9148B29D657B0A39EA228B.description: Determine the appropriateness of methods of communicating explanations based on the audience.

C79DDEF97FF8416085045A051A181082.description: Construct digital or non-digital graphs and tables using proper labels, legends, scales, and titles.

4DB3B53A3DDD48398020519F6FE767F8.description: Communicate explanations using appropriate digital or non-digital technologies.

9A4A28A8F6A44570ACCE308FFCB37BE2.description: Interpret multiple forms of text that offer explanations of natural phenomena.

4CEEC5DD07AC4EC48BD0CE5DECCE22A9.description: Evaluate the trustworthiness of evidence and explanations from a variety of sources.

B9AF3E50973C46E8841735F266014190.description: Discuss observations and measurements used to create scientific explanations.

5CE9142E1E3244CB90B34A0486731A5A.description: Create scientific explanations for how natural phenomena occur.

6271DEB7F2C84BEF817754A455D1E5C0.description: Develop and test a hypothesis based on a scientific explanation.

A7BA6F689DDD448D9C3862D5D8A51EA5.description: Discuss the role of scientific explanations.

F4A6937F27FB409B9EA3451327A5F744.description: Science is a self-correcting way of knowing about the world, where new evidence can change understandings and explanations.

C36BA4D8ED3040D5B98E935E23E73F48.description: Explanations of natural phenomena are communicated in various ways.

DFED8F83A911451EADCDDC6D720006A1.description: Scientific explanations are constructed using reliable, objective data and evidence.

3180F540A0CB48C1AE1F85D5B061F8A2.description: Explanations are used in science to answer scientific questions.

1B8ACA719C654F51BF8B969344F3986E.description: One conflicting study is not enough to cause a scientific explanation to be refined.

B2CB944428ED453FAC0D5783C66DB86B.description: New evidence has refined inaccurate scientific explanations of natural phenomena, such as the Sun revolves around the Earth, different tastes are detected in different areas of the tongue and the eyes are a source of light, allowing vision

C310C85F456646549DC3F17AE1D23150.description: Further investigation can involve a variety of processes, such as continual collection of evidence over time, discussion and debate in the scientific community, conducting multiple investigations over long periods of time and using new technologies and methods that reveal new evidence

1D30112B3C2343C19DD5694DB40376BB.description: Evidence and scientific explanations are subject to further investigation to determine their validity.

9883BC4CF2F54A5A8A85234719DC70CB.description: The needs of the audience influence how science is communicated, such as vocabulary used, level of detail and method of communication

17C759E826AE4A04995C0462AEA2CAE1.description: A scientific explanation can be communicated in different ways depending on audience.

841980F79FA7487583CB14EB47471FAD.description: Scientific explanations can incorporate a variety of texts, such as visual forms; e.g., graphs, tables, flow charts, diagrams, and models, written texts; e.g., research papers and verbal presentations; e.g., stories and discussions

93A9330A77874274B827A2B00E158FB8.description: First Nations, Métis, and Inuit share explanations of natural phenomena through written texts, traditional knowledge, visual forms, verbal presentations and stories and legends

B343B1C8896C4A6F98CD8A3A073BB710.description: Scientific experiments performed with objectivity and a high level of accuracy produce trustworthy evidence to support explanations.

64700D9285254EC1BA7042EF635929D0.description: Scientific explanations can be used to describe natural phenomena such as phases of the moon, hours of daylight, and amount of rain or snowfall (precipitation).

51440D03FBD14E76A55305F3490A69AF.description: Evidence is used to support or contradict a hypothesis.

83A0491E0CCD486A9838EB9EB698FE2D.description: Hypotheses are based on prior scientific knowledge and understandings.

2B5630948C714D18BB15678EE1EF272D.description: Hypotheses are proposed scientific explanations developed prior to conducting an investigation.

3A0D839BEA1641E5A94A777E2BDC4909.description: Scientific explanations must be testable (falsifiable) by an investigation that will either support or contradict the explanation.

2E8FA101BC0548C1B8A97E518928FA95.description: Students investigate and describe the role of explanation in science.

B3B53698BB8349B09C3BA0ABFC09DC24.description: Scientific Methods: Investigation of the physical world is enhanced through the use of scientific methods that attempt to remove human biases and increase objectivity.

236363DF70874BF5998F2C3D2982E38F.description: Predict possible impacts of computers, coding, or technology.

88755E292B854B3AA9C46BD0ACB76E98.description: Discuss how computers, coding, or technology have had impacts.

A0B2727739C64EEBA618E1073A08633E.description: Use a visual block-based language to design code that includes relevant design structures.

384730B000DA4D029DEE6E8C74B00A18.description: Discuss the role of design and coding in society.

9E8F23E458114AE3B25D0B2FB0A9F15A.description: Identify examples of abstractions encountered in daily life.

C867113B72EF44A19355F0FA264B521A.description: Apply abstraction during the design process.

5C3CB64157824218B49A45478EEB5DDA.description: Computers, coding, and technology can be used in ways that have positive or negative impacts.

067F82E47DCF401696816CFEB222EB32.description: Abstraction is used in design and coding of computational artifacts to make problems easier to think about.

7971DAC7C69B43E7968D2AC073B14D92.description: Impacts of computers, coding, or technology may be intentional or unintentional.

12123063779441DB8860DF81E7DFBBAB.description: The use of computers, coding, and technology can have impacts that are personal, social, environmental and economic

E94B36DC536948879F9302E79A0054AA.description: Conditional structures are statements that tell computers to complete different actions based on different situations.

BFB967EE8B8E4E5EACCFDF4F465AA322.description: Sequence structures are ordered sets of instructions within code.

1B5E8892D2824CD3AD6A987F58828378.description: Structures used in coding include sequences, conditionals (if-then-else statements) and loops

82F2ADC0A64847F59B7802819D1624A8.description: Computational artifacts can be designed to address societal needs and wants; e.g., weather modelling communications, automotive controls, medical research and apps

E050ED9272E34A6F953A4BFCC558F902.description: Abstractions can make daily life easier; e.g., simple controls on appliances, light switches, steering wheels and apps

EF0B7AD731C3427BBB5A53B2C8943273.description: An abstraction is a simplified version of something complex.

F3C810F807C04B77B6011DD81B391599.description: Information is data that is organized to be more useful.

8215FB9297174E879F8ECC03580467AA.description: The process of abstraction includes determining what details to keep and what to ignore, removing unnecessary details, identifying important information and generalizing patterns

4100EA82170C40DEBF5B84B4A8B126C7.description: Students examine abstraction in relation to design and coding, and describe impacts of technologies.

B08CB9916302418FA5113507F2A33E26.description: Computer Science: Problem solving and scientific inquiry are developed through the knowledgeable application of creativity, design, and computational thinking.

E67F349164034AEAB4AA7AAEF417BBFA.description: Discuss potential personal, societal, technological, and environmental barriers to living and working in space.

54E1F349756A469B9EBF1EE5D37CF3EC.description: Compare and contrast natural satellites and artificial satellites.

1571807DCF374B10AAC750446332D9F2.description: Identify and compare technologies used to gather knowledge about planets and other objects in space.

EA178D37EB384CE1A91D1A613EEC0229.description: Investigate digital or non-digital resources that contribute to understandings of the solar system.

65F5858F4A5642128990E6CE58D4D3E9.description: Interpret physical, pictorial, or digital models of the solar system.

F381ED2E5C684E59A23B8F29FBE0398C.description: Examine celestial bodies that emit or reflect light.

E67D809EB86D4150B246B90397318849.description: Represent and describe the characteristics of celestial bodies in our solar system.

9C01A5B3EA9E44D5941214FBE8304A96.description: Classify celestial bodies of the solar system as planets, moons, dwarf planets, asteroids, comets, meteoroids, or the Sun.

F881E0A92A2D4DB68AEF8F79AA43C266.description: Name and order the planets in the solar system and identify the location of the main asteroid belt.

CBDE60DF42EB4C45B86947CE546C45DE.description: Knowledge of the solar system continues to develop with further space exploration, discovery, and use of technologies.

3796452FCDD7439398EBAD0D6F2C8EA9.description: Information about Earth can be acquired through exploration of the solar system.

276988397C5742B7B9AF5C7C52E0D94F.description: The International Space Station is a research facility that orbits Earth.

F008C988E7E448FF9ECAC6478F3EA611.description: The first satellite put into orbit by Alberta (Ex-Alta 1) was designed by a group of students and faculty at the University of Alberta (AlbertaSat) and was successfully launched from the International Space Station in 2017.

CED86C2F2F794A0186E70981E8A18561.description: Artificial satellites are constructed and put into orbit by humans.

E49B2BBB30BC4FEA834EAAFB04D4CCB3.description: An orbit is the recurring path of an object around another object in space.

979B75F7AB3C4252BD89856E344604ED.description: Satellites are objects in space that orbit around another larger object.

1CFB771AF4184C66B737DEBC2C7837A6.description: Technologies that are used to explore the solar system include telescopes, satellites, probes, rovers, manned spacecraft and space stations and computer modelling

9A5BED085C59486FB9C8344C2558E546.description: The solar system can be modelled to represent the size of the Sun and the planets and the distance between them.

A3694C45EF5543029BA9996B785A6516.description: Although Pluto was originally classified as a planet, new information led to the reclassification of Pluto as a dwarf planet.

627187646A8D4583871AB8FDCCA62A78.description: An asteroid belt is a collection of asteroids found within the solar system.

8B3821614ED3458DA6D1EB5985B9A811.description: Some celestial bodies emit light and others reflect light.

CAC408E6985F4872959AE084915D3DEC.description: Celestial bodies have characteristics that vary in many ways, including surface conditions; e.g., temperature, gravity, and atmosphere, composition; e.g., gas, ice, or visible rings, size and shape; e.g., round or irregular

4864CF72C012421A9AC667E78CD01D98.description: Celestial bodies are natural bodies located beyond Earth's atmosphere.

0544C2E17F32424885E717D44F213006.description: The solar system is a complex group of celestial bodies that include the Sun (a star), planets and their moons, dwarf planets, asteroids, comets and meteoroids

C4B7C2DC87A746E1A1CADA9F0AFAC74C.description: Scientific exploration of space has revealed that Earth is an interconnected part of a group of planets that orbit the Sun.

259E1CBF51DF41C9B2B683090D122F48.description: Students analyze and represent celestial bodies of the solar system.

E153C7B581384E5EBB32253BC22D3CEB.description: Space: Understandings of the living world, Earth, and space are deepened by investigating natural systems and their interactions.

61869371F4634239B2C64F3C33F3EBBA.description: Discuss plants that are considered sacred to First Nations and Métis.

69C88E0461884CC7A62B9766AD972A43.description: Examine ways that plants and animals rely on each other to meet their needs.

093C32E243F74B4AA4EA70815C2C55DB.description: Design and perform a controlled experiment to show that a plant contains starch.

B2F8F935399449A5B69AC4A5338E261D.description: Design and perform a controlled experiment to show that a plant is releasing oxygen.

2E45D53CFFE34AA08D48E7115948B6B0.description: Design and perform a controlled experiment to demonstrate the importance of light to photosynthesis.

B7E721869290475D9571B6F37EC67AEB.description: Explain the process of photosynthesis and its importance in an ecosystem.

A832C507B6AB491BBCA1E690FCA727E0.description: Examine the diversity of animals and plants in various ecosystems in relation to abiotic components.

EA21FA7142704580BBCB0F00F74778FE.description: Compare the characteristics of two ecosystems.

66DCF620E44C42C2A358597EE1A9C513.description: Create a model or simulation to represent a chosen ecosystem and its characteristics.

99404D37913944C39CBDF1B42E771C46.description: Relate the preservation of various ecosystems to possible actions that address climate change.

71F2B30249D2453FBFA2BB3A3CEBB72F.description: Locate and responsibly examine a local ecosystem in nature using appropriate materials and tools.

DB36BC4BD2954FDEB8E858B50A87E064.description: Represent and connect the biotic and abiotic components of an ecosystem.

098202F2830848669AFA8D6C0E2AC87A.description: There are significant relationships between plants and animals within ecosystems.

C23223238365444D81AD9C314391F8E4.description: Photosynthesis is a process that supports growth and survival in a variety of ecosystems.

3E8C0DFB4EF7420E858385A09CB4A19D.description: The components and characteristics of an ecosystem affect the diversity of the organisms that live in it.

D941833E4347493FB6D67CC722775BF4.description: The offering of tobacco signifies balance and harmony, giving back to the land, respect for the plant and a sustainable relationship

E7FE255E53BE4CC19A438FDEEC7AC91C.description: Certain plants are considered sacred to First Nations and Métis, such as sage, sweetgrass, cedar and tobacco

B0F5BF3172AC41BDB0263C82D510AA17.description: Plants benefit from animals, including humans, to help provide carbon dioxide, which they need to survive.

5F180BD723624F03B61F3503EC4223C3.description: Humans also rely on plants in various other ways, such as food, clothing, paper, building materials, medicine and fuel

76348C056E264127BD45151CD727315E.description: Humans, like all animals, depend on plants to produce oxygen that is used for respiration.

80265FA9FFB94568AEEFF21B8109C217.description: Plants play a variety of roles in an ecosystem, such as photosynthesizing, cleaning and filtering water, reducing soil erosion and providing food and shelter for animals

08396D5B30B440AF914EC5DAF98ECCE5.description: Sugar produced by plants through photosynthesis is often stored as starch.

B1F0DA7D651F4B63B46F6980E1D64EEA.description: The release of oxygen and the presence of starch indicate that a plant has been photosynthesizing.

E45FCC924AF045CCA4F34A51F1EB1824.description: Chlorophyll in plants collects light needed for photosynthesis.

EBB3E7912C2642C89C2C6261265778CA.description: Plants and animals use the oxygen that is released during photosynthesis for respiration.

684609C1190445029B88D5A4FF876209.description: Plants and animals use food produced during photosynthesis to perform vital biological processes.

FC24680235A5413A8A8FD346A5819079.description: Plants carry out the process of photosynthesis, which uses light, water, and carbon dioxide to produce oxygen and food in the form of sugar (glucose).

B7A7886224504774A2DEF69D494B92E7.description: Characteristics of ecosystems that affect diversity of organisms include geographic location, including climate patterns, landforms, and water sources, size, from very small to very large and complexity, including number and types of plants and animals

A4F348B3E59645898BB05B7D2755A71D.description: Ecosystems can be examined using digital or non-digital tools, such as still-image and video cameras and magnifying devices.

3E41420405314B66BFAE3E414788954C.description: Some ecosystems store greenhouse gases and prevent them from being released into the atmosphere, such as wetlands, oceans, forest and grasslands

8B9F1C30E2E44D478B1463F27A45203B.description: Characteristics of ecosystems include climate patterns, size, vegetation structure, animal populations and geographic location

9E38599AA62E435DA9D029506298DE3E.description: There are many types of ecosystems, such as desert, arctic, grassland, wetland, forest and freshwater

39381F7E167E4E7CB84EF0CBFCB70AC9.description: All components of an ecosystem influence each other either directly or indirectly; e.g., animals rely on plants for food, plants need water to grow, energy from the Sun affects temperature and decomposers help return nutrients to the soil

8C376F889C304E0EB4C0A335942F7EDF.description: Abiotic components of an ecosystem include energy from the Sun, water, soil, air and temperature

7FC0DDFB51F24306843BA35ADC8D99C0.description: Biotic components of an ecosystem include plants, animals, and micro-organisms.

87420EFAFAD346289BE1FFEB5D7AE59A.description: Ecosystems are complex systems of biotic and abiotic components.

A34E3C20E20640F6A82E07F65176E91C.description: Students investigate the characteristics and components of and interactions within ecosystems.

9DC909AB97D344BB8A6A79BFEC42D2BA.description: Living Systems: Understandings of the living world, Earth, and space are deepened by investigating natural systems and their interactions.

CD0263A0CD82424DB612BBD1DC6D9446.description: Propose ideas on how local Elders, traditional Knowledge Keepers, and scientists can collaborate to support awareness of local climate and climate change.

6C2BFAFCB8654A99A62B69B7F08A6A19.description: Discuss how scientists, Elders, and traditional Knowledge Keepers can collaborate to develop deeper awareness of the effects of weather on people and environments.

A98FA45ACB034FF9847BAC143891A882.description: Identify and discuss technologies that are used to track and predict extreme weather events.

1C4AD8BB8F2248BCA318C99605BB1E38.description: Relate extreme weather events to specific locations in Canada and on Earth.

92839A231D3047A2BD453C75D4193C67.description: Compare historical observations and measurements of weather and environmental conditions to current data.

32C143E34C7E4E669D5B1109A3699A9D.description: Discuss the effects of climate change on traditional ways of living off the land.

2CE0860BBCA0475C944FEEA59329ADEF.description: Research how climate change is affecting ways of living in northern, Inuit, and/or coastal communities in Canada.

E10A66776AAD494AA2712FBCA4B03D72.description: Discuss agricultural practices impacted by climate change.

DC5BA79977074AB5A078EAB752F0AA24.description: Describe possible effects of climate change on land, plants, humans, and other animals.

4DC63BA0F4954BCABE1D6A976EA4EFD7.description: Identify personal actions that may affect global climate change.

DDDED11D139F47BD98ECD97EA9E470F7.description: Relate impacts of natural processes and human activities on climate change.

E940BB5A95834FDAA395FC89B43DFBC9.description: Describe possible impacts on climate due to interactions between the Sun and Earth's systems.

EA7938FC7AE84E9884C7FC14E5B65E2D.description: Collaboration contributes to a broader awareness of the effects of weather on people and environments.

8D54BAD50E2D4538853EEBFE2F17600E.description: Identifying changes in climate relies on observations and measurements from different points in time.

1647F7761CD1433DA6CE85328CAB3F0D.description: Climate change over time can affect land, plants, humans, and other animals in a variety of ways.

CBB3F96964714A808B11C34A5049E1D9.description: Complex interactions between humans, Earth's systems, and the Sun can impact climate and climate change.

CD640F4D5A174F7A9A871BB6926C27E8.description: Local Elders, traditional Knowledge Keepers, and scientists can collaborate and share information about local climate and climate change.

9E598C33131A477392FBB95E85ECE0C9.description: Traditional knowledge and modern technologies both provide information on long-term climate changes.

2CC2E35D0E214AF8A3163CBD946B1895.description: Technologies used to predict extreme weather events include radars, weather satellites, and computer modelling.

53FA7FB546A043ECBB6869F759BFD2A2.description: Extreme weather events that occur in Canada include tornados, blizzards, torrential rain and wildfires

72965595DD704B29AFB92358DFEF14CB.description: Extreme weather events that occur on Earth include heatwaves, hurricanes and monsoons

55CEBBD4B88A46778BCD8FB15565FA54.description: Climate observations come from a variety of sources, such as recorded information, oral narratives and surface layers, including ice, from different time periods on Earth

5E238500FC7B478C99C2997C5301A49E.description: Climate change can be identified through long-term observation and measurement of environmental conditions, such as sea and ocean levels, thickness and duration of sea ice, permafrost changes and number of forest fires

D41848F80C3845DD9BFE600F67350527.description: Climate change can be identified through long-term observation and measurement of weather conditions, including amount of precipitation, temperature, and number of extreme weather events.

6F93418A198B4D3EB98CC35118D53333.description: Theories about potential causes of the extinction of dinosaurs include worldwide climate change, a catastrophic meteoric event, or volcanic activity.

9DFCC3DDDB7A4AF4A80AD0A58C632AC0.description: Traditional ways of living off the land, including hunting and gathering practices of First Nations, Métis, and Inuit communities, have been impacted by climate change in various ways, such as rising sea levels in coastal areas, changing migration patterns and access to hunting, harvesting, and fishing

E45253A06C95498AA166F85B590B0DAE.description: Climate change can impact agricultural practices, such as crop selection, crop production, harvesting periods and yields, irrigation and pest management

6B648DC283E44E76966A4616611FB850.description: Climate change can affect weather and extreme weather events, migration patterns, water resources and frequency of forest fires

8D2DB2471346491DB317278193FAB4FF.description: Personal actions that can help address human causes of global climate change include reducing personal consumption and waste, planting a garden or buying local produce and using clean, affordable, and reliable energy sources responsibly

CA96F6ABD98140EEA29F42222604A0DD.description: Clean energy production has the potential to reduce net greenhouse gas production.

2464545D85F54A4D811A563DD07DA401.description: The release of greenhouse gases into the atmosphere contributes to the warming of Earth.

26FB0F725D8A44B4915E7A8BBBB51CE4.description: Changes in climate can be caused by human activities, including industrialization and pollution.

7122B5B68F0041CEAA7A20D893F177EB.description: Changes in climate can be caused by natural processes, including volcanic eruptions, meteors, changes in the Sun's output and changes in orbits

D4402E9AD5654B80B339C13F5B746E7E.description: Geographical location factors that affect climate include latitude, proximity to a large body of water, elevation and urban or rural setting

ECC7DB67845A46A88B1138A7519D4E3D.description: Humans rely on the Sun and Earth's systems for a habitable climate.

108DFB087EE1496D806C6FAA8791557D.description: Earth's systems interact with the Sun and each other to impact climate in various ways, including clouds reflecting sunlight into space, greenhouse gases trapping heat from the Sun and ice reflecting light from the Sun

F7805678C6694D9280A142358935D353.description: Students investigate climate, changes in climate, and the impact of climate change on Earth.

0BABF5551F9D42C9BE8160FD764E2642.description: Earth Systems: Understandings of the living world, Earth, and space are deepened by investigating natural systems and their interactions.

951B187107EC40728D09750EE0A29D19.description: Design a device that uses an energy resource, before or after processing, to solve a problem.

0647B2BC77FD438B9B5E0449179EB66A.description: Discuss ways energy resources are used by individuals or communities in daily life.

34FED35A506947A5ABF8B19DE9D7DB88.description: Compare the use of an energy resource before and after processing.

A76257A955C54C0FB435174E3893F658.description: Classify energy resources as being used before or after processing.

68662F4DAA474AFF898877B7F18EB607.description: Examine management of energy resources in various contexts.

1BA5270614384FB399F9324CF5E066AC.description: Examine factors that influence selection of principal energy resources used in Alberta.

B18197AE38324E1D8AE9CEBCF4CC0D87.description: Investigate factors that influence selection of energy resources.

BF89E7C5808747829A48FE35600FD02F.description: Energy resources can be managed for use in daily living.

B9EBE77B2F954A508DE743ED57C0C7CB.description: The advantages and disadvantages of several factors influence selection of energy resources.

25BA25D869A046F29D51C6F749EF379C.description: Energy resources can be used in daily life in various ways, such as heating and cooling, lighting, cooking and transportation

F1C2248D50D848FC8679A6B9710281B0.description: Some energy resources can be used before processing and after processing; e.g., wind can be used before processing to sail a boat and after processing as electricity.

BBB5595E5C05423F91007C5B0BFA83A3.description: Many energy resources are processed into electricity.

020DDC402B674A289C63728A5078BDDC.description: Some energy resources can be used after processing, such as wind, solar, fossil fuels, nuclear, hydro and biofuel

B710C7D7D92645949DD90247DBEB9F54.description: Some energy resources can be used before processing, such as wood, wind and water

4B2D8CF69E6945B2BB1EF6166AC5B5D8.description: Responsible management of energy resources includes minimal disruption to nature, restoration of extraction areas, waste management practices and respect for land and resource rights

1235CAAB006A4738AD44B331992AEE98.description: Factors that influence selection of energy resources include availability and accessibility, societal impacts, economic impacts and environmental impacts

9F289CCBA1A543B5AF775BE8D7349DBC.description: Students investigate energy resources and explain factors that influence their use.

A13E0C50872C44ACA2D5AEFBD9885014.description: Demonstrate and represent an action force and its reaction force in various interactions.

1DFF4B79276B4A639F47303CE192C804.description: Test the plasticity and elasticity of objects.

716281766924431FBD4CA4871B51E5F0.description: Differentiate between temporary and permanent changes.

5B0019B5A392482A91D688253ADE46F3.description: Use materials, tools, and equipment safely while experimenting with forces in interactions.

25C5B6CD11CA4DE49386AD4DB5D3CD28.description: Identify forces that act on an object during an interaction.

5620A6487CFB42599014F5B0572AEFC2.description: Conduct investigations to answer questions about the effects of external and internal forces on objects during an interaction.

CBD5DA2D29884E69A18779AF870ED0CA.description: For every action force, there is an equal and opposite reaction force. (Newton's Third Law)

12C87C4850CF4AC08BB6F9C47BBD3DA6.description: Changes in an object's shape depend on its properties.

AE23CEC570A64994BC3CE4332E3C795B.description: External and internal forces can change the shape, size, or position of objects that interact.

47D6DECBB4BD46AF870DF5D476218CA7.description: One object experiences an action force while another object experiences a reaction force in an interaction.

1B331177A0FA49B2822218353B73E054.description: A reaction force acts in the opposite direction of an action force.

409E834B671F4A939438E30A647835B7.description: An action force is exerted on an object in a particular direction.

F7AF0F2998D04FB6A1CE0B130BAFB23F.description: Elasticity is a property that enables temporary changes in an object's shape; e.g., stretching a rubber band.

D5F3FA461A484D1393FFFE755E1198B7.description: Plasticity is a property that leads to permanent changes in an object's shape; e.g., bending a paper clip.

4BA2DC623CD44AE7BD8D4802072047BF.description: Torsion is a force that twists an object.

BCFF402EE1C14ED785ACA80022682B38.description: Shear is a force that pushes parts of an object in opposite directions, resulting in bending or breaking.

AC238FC93505455BBB8C37B27359F105.description: Compression is a force exerted on an object that squeezes, squashes, or compacts the object.

BF83512B940D4211840F191189A4A079.description: Elastic or spring force is exerted on any object that is in contact with a compressed or stretched elastic object or spring.

C90378E3C8F1410FAD6F1FECB9FE4540.description: Tension is a force exerted by pulling on a string or rope that is connected to an object.

0C91B1343FBA4A69ADBD13E0880D407B.description: Friction forces oppose the movement of objects when those objects make contact with other objects or surfaces.

59C47A43D96D498F82EFEB5BE729ED62.description: An applied force is exerted on an object by a person or another object.

83E2464F7E3F474FADC2E70A4BB95539.description: External forces cause internal forces within an object.

8501667A18E342D58E4E017C72705603.description: Forces that act on an object from outside the object are external forces, including applied force, friction and elastic or spring force

A55046A2AA9C4880ADCD296E0E8D410F.description: Forces within an object are internal forces, including tension, compression, shear and torsion

691BE11A3430457B8B92BD68E373D428.description: Students analyze forces and relate them to interactions between objects.

36EC986C5474427691CC6C9F79A4752A.description: Energy: Understandings of the physical world are deepened by investigating matter and energy.

96F9C6ECCF054C6E8BAD8D53B96143CB.description: Explain the significance of expansion or contraction in the design and construction of structures.

45226A28C926464B8F624F70F6D9B778.description: Hypothesize the effect on aquatic life if solid water were denser than liquid water.

59A0416FD7EF4B0D9B5A07EC47A4FD39.description: Conduct an investigation to demonstrate that liquid water is denser than solid water.

5CD50120824348919E9E3B560D708B38.description: Identify safety practices associated with measuring temperature and the use of measurement tools.

20E53F5E4A8D4B6397635AF745B9BD56.description: Relate the melting/freezing and boiling points of water to the Celsius scale.

01A85B400EBF459F831770D4161EB48E.description: Create a tool that measures temperature based on expansion and contraction of a liquid.

EDC95682AE3A412E98775C61A44E46BA.description: Describe how a liquid thermometer works.

027408E6FD2A4057A2D4E6FA2CC2725F.description: Conduct a controlled experiment to prove the mass of a substance is the same after a phase change.

03E547387F034F18894615D16D3C22BB.description: Explain phase changes of matter when heated or cooled using the particle model of matter.

A71A3711E77744C38AE74D10DD8648B7.description: Discuss the connection between movement of particles and temperature in degrees Celsius.

3FC4ED560BAD42348EA0CE910291E0A5.description: Most matter expands when heated and contracts when cooled.

9D2C8B23B4C84FF1A13C219B2C24BCA2.description: Expansion and contraction of matter can be the basis for the design of tools that measure temperature.

CCBE01E7ED9F4743B8DA505D21C12D1D.description: Particles change speed and distance from each other when heated or cooled.

BC4607C715B3412097EB331F099ED3EC.description: A material's response to temperature change requires consideration when designing and constructing infrastructure, including sidewalks, bridges and roads

781E2D81E2444DE6B3AB6DA3338D43B2.description: The frozen surface of a large body of water forms an insulating sheet of ice that protects aquatic life.

BBB93C33CDDB4B208668C6B5FD2DB218.description: The surface of a body of water freezes when the temperature of the water drops below the freezing point.

5824C7F4067B4D4D9FE13252B2A3DBE8.description: Because of water's unusual property, it is less dense in solid form than in liquid form.

E5CAA0CF49904760AD15BCE3A7E69576.description: Water has the unusual property of having greater volume in solid form than in liquid form.

EE48049B1D3841BD94EA083B5F96B627.description: Contraction is the typical response materials have to cooling.

11E146B9DD904B9D9A7B0D71523F9A1B.description: Expansion is the typical response materials have to heating.

A9DEC08FB88A426FBB74AAFD6B9B7709.description: The Celsius scale is based on the changes of state of water and defines 0°C as the melting/freezing point of water and 100°C as the boiling point of water.

73208CF6F1B6444B9D280B97356143AF.description: Scientists use the Celsius scale to measure temperature in degrees Celsius (°C).

2D0D0CC3A2FD43F59B99FC0A7C21099A.description: A liquid thermometer uses the expansion or contraction of matter to measure temperature using a scale.

963143A7385E45F88EF7843A4CEEB131.description: During a phase change, the volume of the matter may change but the mass remains constant.

D1DB61547A8A48FA9F85D8B834B0859C.description: A phase change is a change from one state of matter to another.

7C4CB6DB245C47949A4C21A79E63DE14.description: As particles slow down, the attractive forces between them increase and the space between them decreases.

A0644D312F014EC19037BC2537200FC1.description: The particle model of matter states that cooling matter causes particles to move slower.

BA09C65C242D48E68A5061FC1F104C0E.description: As particles move faster, the attractive forces between them weaken and the space between them increases.

A1263F5390184BAE86919926B72186B5.description: The particle model of matter states that heating matter causes particles to move faster.

FCEACF53F12C494BA9418FC6B7852A91.description: Students investigate how particles of matter behave when heated or cooled and analyze effects on solids, liquids, and gases.

A765C8EDA4184E2FA3C9DAA90291177F.description: Matter: Understandings of the physical world are deepened by investigating matter and energy.
